values:
As an aspiring writer and filmmaker, there have been instances where I find myself daunted by my own expectations - to think on my feet

and at the same time thinking outside the box, qualities that proved crucial in both fields. It is frightening when you reach a dead end where

you stop challenging yourself and thus stop working when you feel your creative juices have been squeezed to the very last drop. Then

your self-confidence starts to disown you as the feeling of unworthiness begins to tiptoe its way in. Upon almost falling into this dark pit,

my kind documentary film professor introduced me to a surprisingly moving and funny talk by Elizabeth Gilbert, author of world's

bestseller "Eat, Pray Love," dishes on the impossible things we expect from artists and geniuses. Gilbert shares the radical idea that, instead

of the rare person "being" a genius, all of us "have" a genius.


Long before Gilbert had carved a career out of her passion in writing, she had already expressed her interest in the craft. And the only

memory she gained from that was people giving her fear-based reactions: "Aren't you afraid you're not going to find success?""Aren't you

afraid that the humiliation of rejection will kill you?" "Aren't you afraid that you are going to work your whole life at this craft and nothing

is going to come out of it and you're going to die on a scrap heap of broken dreams with your mouth filled with bitter ash of failure?"

Being in a materialistic century (I don't blame us) where the humble journey to success isn't exactly what the public is interested in. And

sadly, there is no stop sign to this mentality. 


Eventually when Gilbert's huge success came in "Eat, Pray, Love," and even then people still treated her like she's doomed. "Aren't you

afraid you're never going to be able to top that?" Gilbert was provoked by all these demeaning responses but has come to realize that

creativity has been inherently linked to suffering, referring to the grim death count in the 20th century of "magnificent creative minds who

died young and often at their own hands" or those who lived longer but seemed to be "undone by their gifts." Gilbert quoted the words of

Norman Mailer, in in his last interview before his death, "Every one of my books has killed me even more." 


So should anybody be expected to be afraid of the work that they feel they are put on this earth to do? What is it specifically about creative

ventures that seem to make us nervous of each other's mental health in a way that other careers don't do? Should we internalize this notion

that creative people across genres have the reputation to have this lapse into self-misery?

To Be Continued…

Let's take a better look
beyond a story book
and learn our souls are all we own
before we turn to stone

let's go to sleep with clearer heads
and hearts too big to fit out beds
and maybe we won't feel so alone
before we turn to stone

and if you wait for someone else's hand
you will surely fall down
if you wait for someone else's hand
you'll fall, you'll fall

i know that i am nothing new
my words might not seem much to you
but brother how we must atone
before we turn to stone

Jakarta was the best decision I've made.






And all the kids they dance, all the kids all night
Until Monday morning feels another life
I turn the music up
I'm on a roll this time
And heaven is in sight

Time really flies. It feels like it's just yesterday when I stood before the towering Burj Khalifa to usher the new year. It's 4 months in, 2 months away from doing my internship, and I feel like I'm one step closer to achieving one (hopefully) hard-earned goal. It's settled for now. Gulf News.

Aside from that, I'm pretty much occupied with the long and tedious process of producing a documentary as well as a short film. I would be lying if I said I'm not mentally and physically drained from the hectic schedule, but I would sin if I said I haven't enjoyed every single second of it. 
 
Documentary is my passion. I take pleasure in knowing that Alfred Hitchcock said, "In feature films, the director is God, but in documentaries, God is the director."  You get to enjoy the thrills of uncertainty, very much so in the Cinema Verite technique. I've only gotten the opportunity to watch 3 documentaries in class since the semester starts, but I am certain to say that my love grew with each subsequent documentary, as they reveal a hidden nature of art expressed by different unique individuals. I aspire to be that individual who would be able to tell a story of another through an artistic lens and draw an impact on members of the audience who watch, but most importantly, "feel" the documentary.

One realization remains: nothing lasts forever.


Spread the love for Japan.

I planned to spend the morning to pack, that includes the dreadful task of sifting the no-longer-useful items and shoving them into the largest possible paper/plastic/garbage bag that I could find. And here I am in the computer room barely 2 hours trying to at least decently accomplish that....I got bored.

I have a big week coming ahead of me. At least I hope it is going to be a great, big week. InshaAllah. My flight to Jordan leaves tomorrow at 8am, I wonder how it would be like flying with Jumanah, the friend that I'm going to spend half of my semester break with in her residential area in Amman. Her family has been so generous and caring towards me and it was awfully nice of them to offer me to come to Jordan, all-expense paid trip. God Bless their family!

The other half of the break, in which I had a choice to whether return to SG or tag along with my mum and her friends to Europe, is something that I hope will rejuvenate my home-sickness! Honestly now I feel like just going back home.........But nevertheless, I am still looking forward to the lovely break.

Fall has finally come to an end! Thank God!

It annoys me to the core that it is hard to find people who are bold enough to pair words up with their actions. Sadly I fall into that category. And I'm deeply regretful of that. I can't even bring myself to act as one person. Why must we have all these masks as part of keeping us "sane"? If anything, that would only thrash our esteem. We would then find ourselves lost in transition.

Only God knows, the thing I'd like to do most right now is just to bask in the serenity of a visually captivating place, a natural surrounding. Only then I can absorb the true beauty of life. The noise of hypocrisy is just too deafening.

It's the start of a new semester today. New courses, new people, new environment. It seems like we are bound to go through this cycle every 6 months. Changes happen after 6 months, nothing stays the same. It is scary to even think that your feelings will remain the same after 6 months. It is almost likely that I feel reborn. Last semester was awesome. I made new great friends from the Sudanese Club, attended the Global Day with them and thought that the new-made friendships will be something I bring with me up to my graduation. But sadly, a few of them are transferring, one of them passed away, the rest remain in state of disbelief and sadness. The youth and vitality that was present from before seemed to have been sucked into the realms of life.  Nevertheless, being a firm believer of Islam (InshaAllah), I believe in the Hereafter and I believe that the challenges that happen in this world are part of increasing our iman, to realise the existence of the Most Righteous and the Most Merciful.

It is always nice to end my summer holidays on a high note. Last year, I capped my summer break with the celebration of Singapore's Birthday. This year, I get to embrace Ramadhan and the Eid celebrations at home sweet home before making my return to the UAE.

Most importantly, this year, I dedicate my prayers and dua's in Ramadhan to my fellow AUS colleagues who passed away recently. May God have mercy on their souls. Amin.

During this holy month of Ramadhan, 2 people I know from AUS died tragically on two separate road accidents; one in Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and the other in Syria.

Muhd. Mutasim Amara, or also known to be Afros by most of his loved ones, left us family and friends on the first day of Ramadhan, while Sima Al-Jundi, on her way to Aleppo to purchase hijabs (weeks after she expressed her intent to start wear hijabs permanently) , met with an accident on Friday, the last 7th day of Ramadhan, 5 days after her birthday. SubhanAllah.

I am truly sad that I have never got the chance to know these two kind-hearted souls on a personal level, though I had conversed with them on a few occasions (Sima and I attended class together last semester). MasyaAllah, both of them made a lasting impact on me with their sweet and angelic smiles even though I was almost a stranger to them. For someone who did not foster close ties with  them before their departure, it is already heartbreaking for me to hear of their sad demise, and cannot begin to imagine what it must be like for her loved ones. The overwhelming response (mostly shock and sadness) from family, friends and colleagues all over just shows how wonderful these 2 people were before. I pray, from the bottom of my heart, that Allah s.w.t grant them the straight passage to Jannah and also the strength for his/her family and friends to go through this painful ordeal.

One thing I'm certain of is that Allah s.w.t loves them more.

Al-Fatihah.

He could even be grateful in a sense that he had no particular area of interest: in avoiding specific goals he had avoided specific limitations. For the time being the world, life itself. could be his chosen field.
- Revolutionary Road

Sometimes boredom  can have its own pros. I was indeed enlightened by a pile of untouched fiction novels (mostly belonging to my sisters) in a slightly hidden corner of the cupboard. I never really knew we had that many books. Even that thought itself gives me jolts of adrenaline boost.
I've always been a believer of judging a book by its cover, literally. So I picked up Revolutionary Road whose vintage look caught my eye instantly. Nevertheless I'm just glad there are enough books to keep me busy and my brain cells activated throughout this rather dormant summer break.

Whenever I'm bored from having nothing to do heh, I have this tendency to google every fascinating country that I grew fondly of in recent years. France, Greece, New York, LA, you name it. I would even imagine settling down  in one of those countries, having a successful career and a happy marriage altogether. Haha, too good to be true ain't it?

But this dream keeps me on my feet and I find myself basking in the renewed sense of energy to live life. Isn't that what life satisfaction should be about? To embark in different journeys in life and foster new relationships with anyone and everyone that cross your path. That's how we learn the essence of life per se. You'll be surprised how a few new encounters can alter your life perception in a way that favors your own mental growth.

I'm not saying you have to be thousands of miles away from home and your loved ones to be able to realize this dream. Heck, with globalisation up to speed, we are all connected in an overwhelming degree that you don't have to be out and about to learn about the world. At the end of the day, the means in which you prefer lies in your own best interest.

As for me, InshaAllah, I'd like to experience the cultures of the world first hand. Having a Sudanese roommate and a Palestinian-Jordanian bestfriend, I feel grateful enough to have created such close bonds with these wonderful beings.  My hunger for intercultural knowledge has given me the strength and courage to have chosen a university in the UAE, but it doesn't just end here. It won't, InshaAllah.

To be honest, I am still very fickle as to whether I should resume blogging here or tumblr (feistelle.tumblr.com), the latter makes it so much more convenient for me. Mainly because I have a deeper fond of photography then...urm writing. heh. It's not that I don't want to, it's just that I find it more tedious to attempt expressing myself in words when I can replace a mouthful sentence with just one brilliant photograph. Let's just say I'm more of a a-picture-speaks-a thousand-words kinda person.

But in God's willing, if I have the urge to unlock my deepest innermost thoughts (they're locked in here somewhere ^^) in this blog, I will.

After a pretty long hiatus, I have decided to resume my proper blogging here:)

So what have I been up to since December 2009?
A series of self-reflecting events that have made me truly understand who I am:) 
And then there was the major "kickass" holiday, the truly unexpected yet pleasant encounter with a Russian and now it's Summerrrrr in AUS.

I have bigger plans for my internship next year (Summer 2010) which I pray would pen out smoothly, Insha'Allah. I need your prayers!:)

As of today, I am currently in Jams room (she's rolling around on her bed as I type) and we have a long day ahead of us:) Jams bestfriend from Abu Dhabi is heading to Dubai to spend a day with us since she's leaving to Thailand/UK next week. As long as we stick to decent fun today I think that should be able to keep us energised till the Finals next Tuesday!

Sometimes all it takes is to break away from your little cocoons and enjoy the pleasures of life with those around you, who I'm sure have their own stories to share. These past few days for me were nothing but plain joyful. There is so much that I've gained just by giving the people around me a chance to reach out. I admit I have not been the most sociable person in the past months. But I guess I still had my own reasons.
Alright, down to the nitty gritty details. My Eid break was spent in 2 totally different yet wholesome environments: Ms Jenifah's awesome American-Malaysian feast & Hafsa's own Tunisian girls' party. If anything, these people have made dorm-life less depressing for me, Alhamdullillah. Hopefully there'll be more of these to come, InshaAllah!
Us doing the Asian peace sign XD They look really ayu in Baju Kurung XD
That's me and Hafsa's adorable little sister Fatoumi XD
And this mouth-watering dish is Tunisian's traditional delicacy, Couscousi! Funny how Hafsa's mum decides to make it every time I decide to stop by XD
*Cheese* on the stairway XD Oh! Oh! Oh! We made that from scratch XD! Strawberry Cheesecake and uhm Vanilla Yogurt Cake smothered in whipped cream and almonds XD Us enjoying the amazing weather at Hafsa's backyard after all the dancing and pizzas XD

Nobody said it was easy
Oh it's such a shame for us to part
Nobody said it was easy
Noone ever said it would be so hard

Please take me back to the start.

Coldplay's Fix You just gets me everytime I listen to it. I'm feeling all better already. The power of music&lyrics.
I'm still bummed from yesterday. I couldn't even enjoy a decent live match of AUS vs AUD (i forced a fake cheer and it sounded pathetic) even after Tumi and I treated ourselves to a caramel frappe...makes me wonder whether caffeine can take a reverse effect of sucking the fun out of you....but kudos to martin and doom who managed to hype me up eventually with their epic jokes. keep it up guys......................

When you're too in love to let it show
But if You Never Try You'll Never Know
Just what you're worth

I know, I know. I haven't done enough justice by updating this journal with mere pictures rather than concrete words of wisdom/reflection. A lot of thought has been put into whether I should set up another journal aside, specially for me to outpour my thoughts and sentiments addressing anything from social, political to self-revelation issues that compel me to pen them down on that particular mean of expression. I might come across as being a late bloomer in the writing world, but I've always managed to convince myself that I'm fully equipped with the means for me to expand my creativity, and that I could and should take up this challenge. And so I did. I opened a new blog weeks ago, determined to bring across to readers aside from myself what I never thought one could do as an aspiring writer : that simple bolt of hope. A hope that a reader could simply find in nothing but an honest confession/discovery of a writer attempting to get a better chance in knowing life. I want to be able to touch people's lives with words that could pierce through even the thickest walls of ignorance or even denial. It all starts with communication.

It was the necessity I felt to strip the world
from everything around me and
exist underneath it all, without
objects, people, light or sound.

The face is the mirror of the mind, 
                       and eyes without speaking 
                    confess the secrets of the heart.

I've been reading a brilliantly inspiring book titled "The Face Behind The Veil". It is a compilation of short personal narratives written by ordinary Muslim women in America, which tell us of their bittersweet experiences encountered in the course of fending themselves in the New World. The more I read on, the more I feel compelled to take up Women in history! Good stuff. 

"I am a second-generation Muslim. I love that I am a link between American culture and Islamic culture, that they can coexist within me" -Zarinah, The New Traditionalist

No one can find the rewind button girl,
                                So cradle your head in my hands,
                                     And just breathe.

Be sleepless.
Sleepless and thinking of me.
Wanting me.
Only me.
Change right now.
Change.
Now I own your thoughts.
I own your breath.
I own your heart.

Everything else falls from you except the possibility of jolting and unforewarned memory
springing out of the dark, rushing over you with
the velocity of heartbreak.

They say, ''Don't perish of sorrow; restrain yourself decently''
Yet the true and only cure of my grief is tears outpoured.

Thank God it's finally the weekend. I went through a rather unstable first week of the 2nd semester what with the 4 classes back-to-back 3 days a week annndd the daunting fact that I ended up having the most intimidating professor for Writing102. I'm trying not to dwell on that though. All in the mind.

On a lighter note, I headed down to the Mall of Emirates with Hafsa and her family this evening, with the school bus. Aha. This time, we boarded the later bus (which supposedly caters to the unisex) that came 10min after the first bus service (females only) to that mall, anddd found ourselves surrounded by hooligans from the Mens' Dorms. Fascinating actually, 'cos apart from the Arabs there were the Korean and Russian students too. Seniors. Haha. Man they were hilarious. Many times Hafsa and I were laughing at the back of the bus.Lol. OH and  the trip back to the campus was seriously an adrenaline boost. The loud music, the speeding (+racing with the other bus-.-), the guys making endless noise. Mannn. It was fun tho. Hahah.

  Time : 23.45
  Venue : Mall Of Emirates
  Going back to campus.

An Arab girl : NO WAIITT!! We're waiting for our friend. Just one.

The Arab Girl : Yes there isss!

It hurts much less now, Thank God.

Watched Twilight for like the umpteenth time and I swear it's more depressing than how it already was the first time round. Oh Carter Burwell is a genius. I'm hooked to the Twilight Score. I recall the days when I had that flute in my hands. haha.

There's nothing much for me to do this break. Apart from catching up with some reading and assisting dad in his CID work, I have to say that facebook is getting onto me each day. I would know why.

Alhamdullillah my overall results for the first semester were more than what I could have prayed for. A GPA of 3.75 is not bad at all *gleaming*.
Now for the upcoming semester, I'm contemplating whether or not to drop management and take arabic language course instead. Not that I'm not ever gonna take up arabic. But it's just a matter of time. Then again, it would be a hassle for me to switch sections for my mcm course as the current schedule doesnt permit me taking mcm and arabic at the same time. *deep thought*. Screw that, I'm just gonna stick to management. I'm sure knowing a thing or two about leadership and organizational skills will benefit me in many ways in future.

The news of the New Year Massacre in the Gaza Strip clearly shocked the Arab World. It was rather heartwarming to see my Arab friends uniting to voice out their utter discontent on this tragedy, condemning the Israeli aggression.
Let us pray for the innocent lives lost during the Gaza Airstrikes and those who are afftected one way or another.

We can only be memories.

Living in another country where i believed religious imperfections are unimaginable has taught me something worthwhile. As much as we shouldn't belittle others of our own kind, we shouldn't regard others superior to ourselves either. He created us equal, one way or another. Undermining that truth leaves us hypocritical.

Edward Cullen ruined it for mortal men.
Screw being a princess.
I wanna be a vampire!

Perfect evening spent with Tumi(left) & Hafsa(right) at the Dubai Festival City.
Weather was uhh-maa-zingg. It was especially felt when we took the free(heh) boat quay ride
just outside the mall. What a way to start the Eid break!

Something really funny happened today in my writing class. This has to do with the professors here being really spontaneous and witty in their remarks. lol. So today we were supposed to do a QUIZ in PAIRS. Yes, a very odd technique but apparently her aim was for us to negotiate with our ''partner'' on the right answer, and in that way she thinks that it would be more beneficial for us (And I so agree.) Anyway, maybe I haven't told you how fond she is in pairing up the opposite sexes together. So this time, she randomly paired us up using the attendance list and I, was made to work with this arab (no surprise) guy okay. So here's the funny part : After my prof called out our names, she went to look at us both and said ''Oh my, aren't you two lovely!'' LOL. My my. I was like ''Thanks Professor, that's a start''. And no, I did not say that out loud. haha. But lucky for me my working partner was totally cool about it.

2 WEEKS!!! 2 WEEKS!!!
I was at the right place at the right time. Alhamdullillah.
